Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Elliptic Curves and Computation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the mid-1980s a flurry of ground-breaking papers introduced polynomial-time elliptic-curve point counting, the elliptic-curve method of factoring integers (ECM), primality proving using elliptic curves (ECPP), and elliptic-curve cryptography (ECC). The original papers triggered thousands of followup papers, demonstrating a spectacular series of interactions between mathematics, computer science, and engineering, with a profound impact on applications: for example, the government's current "Suite B" security standards recommend switching from RSA to ECC.

The "Workshop on Elliptic Curves and Computation" will celebrate the 25th anniversary of these papers and the subsequent 25 years of theory and practice of elliptic-curve computations. This workshop will include the 14th annual ECC workshop. The workshop will take place 18-22 October 2010 at the Microsoft campus in Redmond, Washington, with a full week of carefully selected invited lectures, including lectures on the most exciting recent research in the area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the mid-1980s a flurry of ground-breaking papers introduced polynomial-time elliptic-curve point counting, the elliptic-curve method of factoring integers (ECM), primality proving using elliptic curves (ECPP), elliptic-curve cryptography (ECC). This grant supported a week-long "Workshop on Elliptic Curves and Computation" in October 2010 celebrating the 25th anniversary of these papers and the subsequent 25 years of theory and practice of elliptic-curve computations. The workshop also attracted funding from Certicom, Microsoft Research, and the Pacific Institute for the Mathematical Sciences.

The main scientific objective of this workshop was to collect senior researchers, junior researchers, and students to exchange research ideas, promoting further progress in the area. The Workshop on Elliptic Curves and Computation included the classic subjects of point counting, ECM, ECPP, and ECC, and newer types of elliptic-curve computations such as average-Selmer-rank calculations.

ECC deserves special mention as a topic of tremendous practical importance, accounting for perhaps half of all research papers on elliptic-curve computations. However, ECC does not exist in a vacuum! There are many productive interactions between ECC and other aspects of elliptic-curve computation. For example, current IEEE/NIST/NSA ECC standards specify a clever elliptic-curve doubling algorithm using only 8 multiplications, introduced in a 1986 paper by the Chudnovsky brothers; but the 1986 paper was on ECM and ECPP, not ECC. As another example, the recent advent of "Edwards curves" has brought ideas from pure mathematics to ECC, and then to ECM, and then back to ECC.

Bringing researchers together to see and discuss progress in these topics provided a huge boost to continued cross-fertilization between different aspects of elliptic-curve computations. Microsoft Research generously hosted the workshop at its Redmond campus (Seattle area) from Monday 18 October 2010 through Friday 22 October 2010, covering all lecture-room costs, coffee breaks, and lunches. The workshop attracted more than 100 participants.

This meeting's contributions to scientific activity continued after the workshop. All speakers (except speakers who gave blackboard talks) were encouraged to place their slides online. The workshop web pages now host slides from 23 of the talks to improve dissemination. Most of the speakers also agreed to videotaping; the workshop web pages include professional-quality videos from 24 of the talks.
